item.title: Healing Fire in Londonderry: The Temple Was Built to Burn
item.description: Burning a 75-foot-tall pagan temple in a Republican Catholic enclave on the loyalist Protestant side of Londonderry seemed to many like a bad idea.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors inside the 75-foot temple in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, a city with long Catholic and Protestant divisions.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Turning a Wrongful Imprisonment Into Advocacy
item.description: Eric Volz turned a wrongful conviction in Nicaragua into a vocation, helping other Americans imprisoned overseas.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: "A lot of people were convinced I was guilty. But there's only one truth. Facts are facts," said Eric Volz.

item.title: World Briefing: Sierra Leone: Citizens Told to Stay Home to Halt Ebola
item.description: Sierra Leone’s six million people were told on Friday to stay home for three days, except to attend religious services, as the West African nation attempted a final push to rid itself of Ebola.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Cambodia: Another Khmer Rouge Member Is Charged
item.description: An international judge at a war crimes court in Cambodia charged another former Khmer Rouge member with crimes against humanity on Friday.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Labour Leader Starts Bid for Prime Minister
item.description: Ed Miliband, leader of the opposition Labour Party, began his campaign on Friday to become Britain’s next prime minister.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Shiite Militias in Iraq Back Off Boycott Over U.S. Strikes on ISIS
item.description: A message of support from Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, a religious leader in Iraq, apparently has the militias cooperating with the role of the United States.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and OMAR AL-JAWOSHY

item.title: Militants Take Hostages in Deadly Attack on Mogadishu Hotel
item.description: The Shabab claimed responsibility for the attack, in which at least seven people were killed, including a Somali ambassador.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED IBRAHIM
item.media:description: Security forces exchanged gunfire Friday with militants from the Shabaab Islamist group who attacked a hotel in Mogadishu, the capital.

item.title: Hurdles Loom in Iran Nuclear Talks, U.S. Official Says
item.description: An initial accord will not be possible unless the Iranian leadership makes “tough decisions” before Tuesday’s deadline, a State Department official said.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif of Iran, left, conferred with a staff member Friday after a negotiation session over Iran’s nuclear program.

item.title: Amanda Knox Acquitted of 2007 Murder by Italy’s Highest Court
item.description: The acquittal of Ms. Knox and her former boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito, ended a long-running legal drama over the killing of a British student.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Amanda Knox during an interview on ABC's "Good Morning America" in New York last year.

item.title: Poland Charges Russian Air Traffic Controllers in Crash
item.description: The 2010 plane crash in western Russia killed President Lech Kaczynski and 95 top-ranking officials traveling with him.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Israel Releasing Impounded Palestinian Tax Revenue
item.description: The move by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was seen partly as indicating a desire to ease tensions, but also reflected advice from security aides.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Celebrating John F. Burns, War Reporter and Witness to Era-Defining Events
item.description: The two-time Pulitzer Prize-winning correspondent has written his last dispatch for The New York Times — for now.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN CHIRA
item.media:credit: Michael Kamber for The New York Times
item.media:description: John F. Burns interviewing Iraqis after the capture of Saddam Hussein in 2003.

item.title: At Least 9 Dead as Militants Attack Hotel in Somali Capital
item.description: Al-Shabab militants blasted their way into a Mogadishu hotel on Friday and took up positions inside, killing at least nine people and exchanging fire with security forces seeking to recapture the facility, a Somali police official said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Houthi Forces Move on Southern Yemen, Raising Specter of Regional Ground War
item.description: On a second day of Saudi airstrikes against Houthi rebels in Yemen, Saudi and Egyptian officials declined to rule out the possibility of ground troops.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Yemenis hoard ammunition boxes from army depots in the port city of Aden. Houthi-aligned forces advanced on the southern port town on Friday.

item.title: In Mexico, Firing of Carmen Aristegui Highlights Rising Pressures on News Media
item.description: Many believe Ms. Aristegui, a leading radio personality, and her team were fired after a report on a mansion built for the president’s wife by a company with lucrative government contracts.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Carmen Aristegui, a prominent radio journalist fired by MVS, waved to supporters after speaking with fellow journalists outside the radio station in Mexico City this month.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Karl E. Meyer and Shareen Blair Brysac on ‘The China Collectors’
item.description: The authors have written a rollicking account of the acquisition of Chinese art and antiquities by Americans who came to China in the 19th and 20th centuries.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
The China Collectors: America's Century-Long Hunt for Asian Art Treasure (Book)
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Israeli Center-Left Leader Seeks Path Forward
item.description: Isaac Herzog, who ran to unseat Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, does not see the campaign or its result in simple win-loss terms.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A rotating campaign billboard in Tel Aviv showing Isaac Herzog, the leader of the Zionist Union, left, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, right.

item.title: Co-Pilot in Germanwings Crash Hid Mental Illness From Employer, Authorities Say
item.description: Among the items found at Andreas Lubitz’s home was one doctor’s note excusing him from work the day of the crash and another that had been torn up.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY, DAN BILEFSKY and NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: Flowers at the monument in memory of the 150 victims of the Germanwings crash in Le Vernet, in the French Alps, on Friday.

item.title: Australia Warns of Terror Threat in Kenyan Capital
item.description: The alert from the Australian diplomatic branch in Kenya follows a similar advisory two days ago from the United States about neighboring Uganda.
item.dc:creator: ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: France Seeks U.N. Security Council Resolution on Mideast Talks
item.description: Laurent Fabius, the French foreign minister, said France would consult with other Council members soon over a framework for negotiations.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
